column4: damn i get crazy...... i did sudo apt-get isntall linux-source and build-essentials... unpacked the source: sudo tax -xjvf linux-source-2.6.22.tar.bz2 went into that folder and did: sudo make oldconfig.. and then sudo make-kpkg --initrd --revision test1 kernel_image kernel_headers BUT it crashes after 40 minutes of compiling can anyone help me?
depends on the error
unended #ifndef and include/linux/pci.h:72: Error: expected specifier-qualifier-list before Â»typedef
thats not really enough, you need about 20 lines of output at least
http://pastebin.com/m293dfca7 there is the error i translated some messages from german to english
looks like your headers differ from your kernel version (but reading your earlier comment I don't think thats the case)
isnt there a way to check that?
well, are all your packages from the ubuntu repo, what version of the kernel are you playing with
http://pastebin.com/m5312589c theres my usr/Src folder
that all looks spot on
why are you re-compiling the kernel, what are you changing ?
i need for an application static oss compiled instead of alsa
and thats all you've changed, you used the same .config from the ubuntu source package
i didnt change anything
i used: sudo make oldconfig
Hmmm and thats failing, interesting
i have no idea what im doing wrong
oldconfig should work, I can't see anything obvious
ist there kind of a checkinstall option?
after a clean up and recompile it crashes on another step
way earlier than before
any idea how to check
im back in a few trying to check my ram
are you there?
I am now,
I had to pop out
i found the error 99,99% it is the error what i found
what is the problem
its my ram
oooh really, thats a good find
i made a test in my bios and that said everything fine
but memtest on ubuntu says errors and errors
good find, well done
after removing each after another and rechecking i found the buggy ram.. but i can bring it back for guaruantee
excellent
but thanks anyway for trying to help me... i appreciate it
you helped yourself, thats the best help there is, well done
how did you install it
read the script and what it does, then undo it
thats one of the draw backs of not using a package manager
i looked through the script but cant find something to uninstall
avira wasnt in the distros so ;)
well, you can either work through the script, or contact the avira vendors and ask them for support
depends what your router will support
router will support any dns server
your router can have any dns server installed on it ?
what OS is your router running
no i think we missed each other in this conversation. i can set manually dns server ips and i want to set the one to my little lan one
oh, just use bind then
bind is a dns server?
it is
thanks a lot ill try it
can you help again? iev found bind9 and already installed is bind9-host which one to use?
you need bind9
isnt dnsmasq easier to configure for my purpose?
it's up to you
you asked for opinions, I said bind
your right, but i found just dnsmasq havent seen it before and thought it might be easier to configure and to maintain
in my opinion, no
emmulate it for what
what you want to use it for will define how it maybe possible
what application are you using ?
just chose another input output port, say IR, bluetooth, etc etc
sorry didnt get what you mean
I assume you mean a serial port as a comport (maybe wrong assumption)
IR/blueooth etc are all "com ports"
RS232, serial, com port and in the future it will be connected to a kind of a microkontroller
ah, I don't blieve you can just make a device node for it , no
sorry for not talking about the whole thing its 7 o'clock in the morning ;)
how about loop mount from one /dev/ttyx to /dev/ttyx+1 ? and connect to them
you don't mount com ports
http://www.tibbo.com/vspdl.php is that maybe what im lookin for?
could work
thanks for your answers and ill give it a shot now
I've never seen that packages
just found it on a forum
no
it seems many other people are having problems: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1306333&page=1
transfers under Debian with the same external drive are 'normal' for USB 2.0. hdparm suggests slow RW also on Ubuntu.
a lot of those posts are firmware specific
i see. i have installed no firmware to support this Western Digital drive on either Ubuntu or Debian.
that you know of
it is a fresh install of Ubuntu 9.10. i am an experienced Debian user of some 12 years and am sure i have not installed any firmware to support this brand new external device.
i suspect a problem at the kernel level, as some bug reports suggest.
what about the firmware that's built into the kernel ?
yes, this is my suspicion

searching further i see a great many people struggling with transfer rates to USB 2.0 compliant mass storage devices. i'll try an upgrade of Ubuntu and report back if i note improvements with hdparm et al.
they are environment variables

yes i know that. as i said, i'm used to gentoo for example, where i can set them in /etc/make.conf permanently. if i wish to change them for one single compilation, i can set them temporarily of course. but i don't want to do it every time.
set it in your shell
that way everytime your shell is launched it's alaready set
i thought about that, i was just curious if there's another way, exclusively for make settings to be stored. but thank you, i guess there's nothing alike. just wanted to be sure :-)
gentoo does it's own thing
i know. just an idea because i used it for a long time, i'm still "thinking gentoo" i guess ;-)
